title: 108_hr4915
content: The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It introduces an exclusion for gain from stock of small, publicly traded companies in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" excludes gain from the sale of section 1203 stock held for over 1 year for non-corporate taxpayers. The exclusion is limited to $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately) per taxable year. 1203 stock refers to stock in a qualified small business C corporation acquired after the enactment date, either for money, property, or as compensation for services. The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" excludes gain from the sale of section 1203 stock held for over 1 year for non-corporate taxpayers. The exclusion is limited to $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately) per taxable year. Qualified small businesses are defined as domestic C corporations with a market capitalization not exceeding $150,000,000 at the time of stock acquisition. The reporting period for determining the value of stock in a corporation is based on the most recent annual or quarterly report filed with the SEC. The rules of section 1202 apply for aggregation purposes. Additional rules under subsections (f) to (k) of section 1202 apply, with a modification in subsection (j)(1)(A). Conforming amendments are made to sections 642(c)(4) and 643(a)(3) of the Code. Section 1202 is amended to include section 1203. Various sections of the Code are updated to reflect this change. A new subsection is added to section 1202 regarding section 1203 stock. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendments made by section 1203 provide an exclusion for gain from stock of small, publicly traded companies. This applies to securities acquired after the enactment of the Act.
